i would also like to propose @undefined the possibility of something like a #curriculum room that would work as follows:

- people can tag links shared in <#1278081837780041749> with @curriculum and if they are accepted by you, they are posted in that group, that only you and potentially selected staff have write access to.

the reasoning is that if there is something like an accepted unofficial curriculum, there can be an implicit assumption/expectation that everyone has stayed up to date on what the community leaders consider to be important. 

that way conversations can go past explaining the essays/videos and instead to discussing the contents and implications of such.

the downside of this idea is that it obviously puts more on the plate of the person tasked with curating. otoh the upsides as a community good are quite large over time imo.

You say that people are following the USA election in the Asia Pacific region. Is there consensus about which candidate is most likely to prevent conflict?
Yes, it's going to be weird when people start calling me Max (not my name). I'd rather change my name to my preferred handle.

The concern about escalations in nation state superpower conflict is arguably wide. @undefined. Here in the Philippines, there are many who support expanded US military base access due to South China Sea tensions and then there are also those who worry that expanded US military base access would make the ASEAN country -- close to Taiwan island -- an unfortunate proxy / pawn in any conflict. Many in ASEAN arguably are worried about being collateral damage or unintentional proxy to superpower nation state conflict. If the most recent pew surveys are reliable, ASEAN opinion is arguably pretty even, about slightly over 50% favoring PRC versus around 49% favoring US. I am guessing many in Malaysia, Singapore etc are actually fairly pro-PRC compared to the mainstream opinion in North America (in some ways due to infrastructure Belt and Road investments etc), grab a periodical like Lian He Zao Bao in Singapore to take a look.

In any case, I only brought up this topic due to the earlier mention of November 5 election. It is a super relevant election (and people follow it nervously) -- many in the ASEAN region feeling like being on the knife's edge are hoping for at least sensible leadership on all sides so that tensions are managed responsibly and escalations do not occur.

A lot of folks in the Asia-Pacific region around Singapore are also nervously following this November election. After Russia-Ukraine European theater and Gaza Middle East theater, any escalated conflict in Asia-Pacific theater featuring superpowers along the first island chain would make the two former theaters feel like appetizers to the main meal -- in a not so good kind of way. This broader region hosts arguably over ~60% of world's trade passage, nearly over ~60% of the world's population, and possibly over ~60% of the world's military firepower arsenal. Hopefully whoever comes out on top on November 5th has the sensilbility to not rock an already unsteady boat.  To peace (or at least detente or some kind of mutual understanding to not escalate).

That the US Indo-Pac Command and the PRC Southern Theater Command just spoke recently...is a welcome sign for stability.

On side note: this feeling of being in an intensely divided era and living on the knife's edge of intense nation state rivalry makes the peaceful alternative global network initiatives Balaji is leading even more relevant -- for us, for our families and communities, and also for future generations.

This is great I‚Äôm similar but I do use whey because I‚Äôm 91kg and it‚Äôs just hard to get enough whole food protein.

It‚Äôs pretty dialed in now so I don‚Äôt track anymore or count macros, as I know the portion sizes and frequency by heart now.

I also cycle bulk and lean alongside my workout regime. I do 2xDay training. Morning mountain run and afternoon weights. When I‚Äôm doing longer runs or I‚Äôm in a bulking phase with heavy weights, I will eat more carbs ‚Äî rice, pasta, even quality breads.

When I‚Äôm not burning as many calories on the runs or I‚Äôm trying to lean out more, then I try to get very restrictive on carbs and rice only or replace all fast carbs with salads.

Lastly, I try to do a lot of probiotic stuff for gut health like kefir, kombucha, picked stuff, Greek yoghurt, fresh fruits and veggies, sauerkraut, kimchi, etc, and I try to eat a ton of raw fruits and veggies.

And of course try to mostly abstain from alcohol. Some studies show the body can‚Äôt even burn fat at all for up to 48 hours after consuming alcohol, as the system shifts to processing the alcohol.

I am very grateful for the opportunity to listen to and learn from so many talented folks here. I wish I could stay longer beyond a visit. Looking foward to meeting everyone, grabbing a coffee together, and learning about alternate futures in which our existence is not tied to a national ID card/national passport, in which being accused of "unpatriotic" is not looked down upon, in which McCarthyist finger-pointing is no longer a thing.  Nationalism is on a hyperdrive in parts of this Asia-Pacific/Indo-Pacific region (where many political and civilizational/cultural boundaries often match) and at times it feels like nation-state fueled superpower rivalry could put the entire region on a knife's edge.

Ideally: low carb, max 25g sugar/day, 3 real meals per day as a base proper breakfast, lunch, dinner. Carbs and sugar only before endurance exercise (road biking). 2x grams per kg bodyweight protein from real food (fish, eggs, meat, dairy, chickpeas, etc.) not shakes, 2150 calories base per day (500g weightloss per week). Track everything in myfitnesspal. Most important utilities: kitchen scale + airfryer.

Strategy for network school: follow vegan blueprint meals, supplement as needed using the small kitchen.

- The Network State by Balaji
- Sovereign Individual by James Dale Davidson and William Rees-Mogg
- What's our problem by Tim Urban (slightly different take. Identifies largely the same issues as Balaji, but very different and frankly less practical conclusions)
- Snow crash by Neal Stephenson. Fiction, but a really interesting exploration of the field (and just super fun).

Crypto:

I have a slightly different take here mostly because I'm not a Bitcoin maximalist and think many of these books are far too simplistic. So take all of them with a grain of salt.

- The Bitcoin Standard by Saifedean Ammous. Lays out the reasoning for wanting decentralized money well.
- Read, Write Own by Chris Dixon
- Snow Crash works for this category too

AI related:
- Daemon by Daniel Suarez (fiction)
- Superintelligence by Nick Bostrom is the classic here, though getting outdated
- Our Final Invention by James Barrat
- The Coming Wave by Mustafa Suleyman

Singapore bonus:
- Third World to First by Lee Kuan Yew, about how Singapore was developed. Also relevant for Network States.

its a great read! it describes the evolution of the internet, the protocols, corporate networks vs protocol networks, speculators vs builders, and lots more.

The constant spinning in a D3 force simulation is typically caused by an imbalance in the forces applied to the nodes in the graph. In your case, the radial force may be causing this behavior, as it constantly pulls the nodes toward a specific point. Here are some suggestions to avoid the spinning:

1. **Reduce the strength of the radial force:**
   The radial force might be too strong, so you can try reducing its impact or even removing it temporarily to see if it stops the spinning.

   ```js
   .force('radial', d3.forceRadial(50, SIMULATION_WIDTH / 2, SIMULATION_HEIGHT / 2).strength(0.05));
   ```

   You can experiment with different `strength` values to find the right balance.

2. **Add a force to dampen the motion (force simulation velocity decay):**
   D3 simulations have a `velocityDecay` parameter that can help slow down the motion over time, reducing or stopping spinning.

   ```js
   this.simulation = d3.forceSimulation()
       .velocityDecay(0.9)  // Adjust this number (0.9 is a typical value for damping)
       .force('link', d3.forceLink().id((d: any) => (d.id)).distance(100))
       .force('charge', d3.forceManyBody().strength(-300))
       .force('center', d3.forceCenter(SIMULATION_WIDTH / 2, SIMULATION_HEIGHT / 2))
       .force('radial', d3.forceRadial(50, SIMULATION_WIDTH / 2, SIMULATION_HEIGHT / 2));
   ```

   A higher `velocityDecay` value (closer to 1) slows down the motion more quickly.

3. **Ensure there are no excessive charges or imbalances:**
   Sometimes, an overly strong charge force can create erratic motion. You might want to experiment with the charge strength to find the right balance between stability and attraction.

   ```js
   .force('charge', d3.forceManyBody().strength(-100));
   ```

   Reducing the charge strength should help stabilize the layout.

Try these adjustments, and they should help to stop or reduce the spinning behavior of your graph.

Hey @undefined, managed to build a Farcaster Vizualizer https://farviz.xyz with the specs that you suggested.
Was new to farcaster development so it was a great deep dive. Here is how we achieved it:

First, we tried with hubble endpoints[1], but the issue was clear each user was causing us 4 api calls[2], to get to the followers from usernames, also the time machine functionality was not possible due to the latest data hubble api provides.
Then we ran our own hub snapshot and used it to backfill a postgres database(still backfilling 400k/800k Farcaster id‚Äôs) [3]
The data is still backfilling so currently some of the users would fetch empty results.
The frontend is written in react and we are using d3 for visualization as a graph. backend is written in node which for now just queries the postgres db

We can optimize the queries further to reduce the query time for large queries, also let us know if we could add any other functionality to it. Also now since we have all the data in postgres feeding from hubble, we can do a lot of things with this
@undefined and I worked on this so anyone who wants to know more or contribute, let us know

[1] https://docs.farcaster.xyz/hubble/hubble#hosted-instances
[2] https://docs.farcaster.xyz/reference/hubble/httpapi/links
[3] https://github.com/farcasterxyz/hub-monorepo/tree/main/packages/shuttle

If we adopt a common diplomacy protocol ... 

...**we could explode in total size. **(community of communities)

How? One important agreement would be that of joining acknowledgement lists.

One new society could be acknowledged, and based on rules, other societies may follow automatically or manually but quickly.

**How quick we get to this picture of The Network State is really up to us, isn't it?**

Sorry it's early morning and my brain is pumping ideas.
Let me turn this into a thread. Please jump in if you like.

**DIPLOMACY PROTOCOL** 
For standardised quick communication between communities based on **acknowledgement**.

Here's how it works:

**STEP 1. Acknowledgement**

Each community keeps a list of other communities it ***acknowledges***.

A world map currently is essentially from the perspective of a citizen of a country. e.g. Europeans put Europe in the centre.

So each community will have their own world map, on which flags from other acknowledged communities could be displayed.

A basic protocol of acknowledgement could include
**- 1 url at which census data can be fetched**

(Probably no need for blockchain, because in the end it's all on the basis of trust and acknowledgement.)

Example summary data:

```
Network School Forest City
153
ns.com
```
1st line, the full name
2nd line the registered population count
3rd line a website

Could extend this with real estate footprint (m¬≤), or turn it into a key value map, with a few required properties and then more and more optional but standardised properties.

**Step 2. Agreements**

After acknowledgement, there are many agreements you can imagine. 

e.g. It's easy to imagine a trade agreement if the communities are professional guilds. 

**Step 3. Information Technology**

Using a standardised protocol, you can now implement that protocol as an API (rpc).

***This can formalise and streamline processes; 100x it in speed compared to the current bureaucracies.***

e.g. A formal request for a meeting between representatives.

e.g. A formal request for AID.

Every agreement, would have a standard list of functions to call.

---

**If we begin with the end in mind, we can build in a straight line towards it. **

(If we do not, how long would it take to get there?)

`Request for Comments`
Diplomacy Protocol

A diplomacy protocol. That'd be interesting... ü§î

With a standard progression...
1. Acknowledge first ‚Äî> 2. Agreements (an over time standardised list of template agreements)

With a standardised format, so we can build APIs to interact between communities programmatically.

We could craft an RFC / proposal together

TLDR: the Network School is about frontier, not fancy. We focused on making it affordable for the dark talent, and getting a place where we could scale the community and edit the physical buildings. Some reflections on drivers for crypto's legal victory (for now) against establishment witch-hunting, to draw parallels to what network state/network society movement may eventually need (not an exhaustive list):
- Leadership, inspiration, and steel will by tech entrepreneur stalwarts (e.g. Brian Armstrong, Winklevoss brothers, etc).  TNS Parallel: In this parallel society movement we have the strength of Balaji, Bryan Johnson, maybe Vitalik, etc.
- Use cases that go beyond technical papers to a burgeoning economy. TNS Parallel: Network society economy parallel to crypto economy.
- Movement value proposition going mainstream --  BTC from an initial techie fringe BBS-board thing (pre-2013) to becoming a grass-roots one that even a cabbie in Cambodia can understand, recognize, and own. TNS Parallel: a thousand netizens -> to a million+ netizens.
- Distributed political power, especially in young voters, as crypto vote has become a critical constitutiency in almost every voting district (at least in the US), with enough passionate voters to swing the election direction. TNS Parallel: If there is a sigificant number of voters, especially young voters (longer vote lifetime), legally present in almost every significant jurisdiction and constituency, who believe in network societies or are netizens too, then establishment politicians will think twice about accusing, banning, or calling "threats to democracy."

One of the lessons from crypto projects -- from XRP to ETH, for example -- is that the establishment would try to throw accusations years down the line that would have major impact on public perception and growth of the network, as well as major legal battle (in the case of XRP). Eventually victory for crypto/decentralization/network, but earlier legal planning may have prevented some of those headaches.

Wrote this on my Substack, would love to discuss: I feel like the history of Network States is a topic that needs more intellectual and scholarly attention: 

https://substack.com/@sterlinlujan/p-148209257

Here is a bit from the article: 

"A network state can theoretically be recognized if it exists alongside other states, but that is not a prerequisite. Geographical constraints or political boundaries do not limit their formation. One critical understanding of network states is that they do not have to be coercive or mandatory, unlike nation-states. They can and should be voluntary. The historical root of the network state was philosophical and political, with no technological ingredient. That original idea is called ‚Äúpanarchy.‚Äù

mhh good question! I believe the NS should achieve both immediate impact and long-term cultural significance, so there could be a dual strategy. On one hand, short, viral content ‚Äìfor spreading awareness quickly and engaging a broad audience (e.g. viral videos, social media campaigns, eye-catching infographics).
On the other hand, i think it's equally important to invest in creating enduring cultural artifacts that will stand the test of time. e.g. substantial works like books, films, and documentaries that delve into the philosophy, history, and aspirations of the NS. This could help establish the intellectual and cultural foundation of the community while also ensure that our ideas are taken seriously and studied by future generations.
While network states can be created faster than physical territories, the culture we build must be robust and substantial üôå

here's a personal hack that worked like magic for me: i would normally max out at 5 mins and vipassana meant close to 9 hours of daily practise.

3 months before going for the course, I & a friend became eachother's accountability partners.

We would message each other daily, (and honestly!), on our practise. Started with 5mins, slowly upped it in increments of 5 to eventually reach 30. And then higher. I guess this works the same way as gym reps - you just develop the right 'muscles' so to say and its no longer an ordeal.
